PEACE PROSPECTS.
div.p: PROGRESS MADE. RUSSIAN ARROGANCE.

Washington, June‘16. M; Takahira notified President Roosovelt the refusal of Japan to send plenipotentiaries to Europe. Russia accepted, and joined Japan, in asking that the meeting should take place here. (Reuter)

LondoN June 16. The announcement of the selection of Washington as the meeting place of the plenipotentiaries seems to imply that progress is being made in the direction of peace, otherwise nothing whatever is known. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, Juuo16. The press continues to comment arrogantly upon the peace suggestions, declaring that Japan needs peace more than Russia: (R.)
TSAR AND THE ZEMSTVOS. THE COMING RECEPTION.

St. Petersburg, June 16. The Tsar having announced that he would receive some of the delegates of the Moscow Congress of Zemstvos, but not all, the delegates have decided to decline the audience (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, June 16. The Tsar’s final decision regarding the audience to the Zemstvos will be communicated to them on Monday. It has boon determined that this audience must bear a political character, and the question of its reception eclipses that of peace in the public mind. (R.)
RUSSIAN RAILWAY STRIKE.
A PAR-REACHING THREAT.

Moscow, Juno 16. A meeting of railway engineers held here has decided that its members will join a general political strike upon the first signal, for tho purpose of entirely stopping the economical life of the country. (Reuter.)
RUSSIAN MARINE MINISTER - RESIGNS.
St. Petersburg, June 16. Admiral T. C. Avellan has resigned the Ministry of Marine. (Reuter )
THE GRAND DUKE ALEXIS.

St. Petersburg, June 16. The Tsar has accepted the resignation by the Grand Duke Alexis of the supremo command of the fleet and Navy Department, but he retains the dignities of Grand Admiral and Aide de camp to the Tsar. (Reuter.)
THE MOROCCO QUESTION.
THE POWERS AND A CONFERENCE.

London, June 16. Austria; Italy, and America have intimated that they are prepared to join in a conference on the subject of Morocco, provided always that the Powers chiefly concerned accept; the invitation. (Reuter.)
M. ROUVIER'S SUCCESSOR.
paris, Jane 16. M. Merlon, Deputy, succeeds M. Rouvier at the Finance Ministry. (Reuter.)

Paris, June 16. M. Ronvier abandons the Ministry of Finance and takes that of Foreign Affairs only. The German Ambassador, Prince de Radolin, is conducting important discussions with M. Rouvier. (Reuter.)
DEATH OF MAJOR WISSMANN.
ACCIDENTALLY SHOOT’S HIMSELF.
Berlin, June 16. Major Wissmann, ex-Governor of East Africa, has accidentally shot himself, and is dead. (Reuter.)
THE LATE M. DELYANNIS.
DIED IN ABSOLUTE POVERTY.
Athens, June 16. M. Delyannis died in absolute poverty. Two nieces with whom he lived will receive a pension from the State. (Reuter.)

ATHENS, June 16. Great Britain, France, and Italy have sent the wannest condolences to Greece on acconnt of the assassination of M. Delyannis. The body lay in state on a catafalque in the Chamber yesterday. (Reuter.)
CHOLERA IN RUSSIA. St. Petersburg, June 16. Cholera has appeared at Tomsk, and on the Siberian railway. (Reuter.)
PLAGUE CASE AT MANCHESTER.
Manchester, June 16. There has been a death from plague on board the SS. Seacok” which has arrived from Buenos Ayres via Hamburg. (Reuter )
HONORS FOR LOCAL OFFICIALS.
London, June 16. The King has appointed H. E. Boutros Pasha Ghali, Grand Cross, and Mr. E. H. Vin-oent Corbett, Knight Commander, of the Vio-torian Order. (Reuter.)

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: // Giro del Hondo in 80 fiiorni (Round the World in 80 Days) drew a large and delighted audience to the Alhambra last night. The play was a great success. It will bo reproduced to-night and twice tomorrow, in the afternoon and evening.

div.head: Accident in Harbour
div.p: On Wednesday, on the departure of the Khedivial mail steamer "Ismailia," and just after the ship had left the quay, a sailor of the crew was knocked off the ship into a lighter while some merchandise was being slung into it, and was seriously injured. He was removed to the Government Hospital.

div.head: Mr. Jones and Mr. Brown
div.p: A native contemporary announces that the Cairo Gon-vernorat has received news from Maghaga markaz that the police there have arrested two Englishmen, named Mr. Jones and Mr. Brown. Each of these persons were found in possession of a donkey, which had been stolen from the Bab-el-Louk stand at Cairo.

div.head: Alexandria Tramway Co
div.p: The rumours as to the approaching extension of the Alexandria tramway system to Montazah are without foundation, and have apparently only been set on foot for the purpose of encouraging speculation in land in the eastern district of Alexandria. The company will come to a decision as to the extension of the Ramleh lino to Mohamed Aly-squaro on Tuesday week.

div.head: Egypt’s G.P.O. in 1400 B.C
div.p: Professor Sayce, lecturing in London last, week, said the civilised Oriental world of the Mosaic Age was us highly civilised as our own of the present day. Correspondence from the Egyptian Foreign Office of 1400 B.Ci was contained in the cuneiform tablets discovered at Tel-el-Armana nearly twenty years ago. Well-organised postal services, high roads, colleges, and libraries existed, and there was “ample evidence that monarchs were as anxious to protect the trade of the country as Mr. Chamberlain today.”

div.head: North German Lloyd
div.p: The S.S. “Schleswig,” of the Norddeutscher Lloyd, left on the 14th inst with a total of 220 passengers for Naples , and Marseilles. It may interest our readers to know that in order to meet the wishes of many Egyptian residents, the directors of this company have ordered the steamer to leave Naples during Saturday night or quite early on Sunday, so that passengers for Marseilles will be able to land there by Monday afternoon, instead of Tuesday as hitherto. The next departure of the “Schleswig" will be on the 5th July, and we hear that the bookings for this fine ship are coming in rapidly.

div.head: THE MAHMAL THEFT. DISCOVERY OF THIEVES. BOOTY TRACED.
div.p: XWith reference to the recent theft from the Mahmal caravan, the Cairo Gonvcrnorat reports that it appears from the investigations made that the thieves ore Amdrous Melnka, Said Hannalla, a money changer, Ibrahim Ashour, a labourer, and Mankarins, a barber. These men divided the money among themselves, bought a house at Haret el Nasarn, 1,500 metres of land at Shoubra, and were negotiating for the purchase of a honse at Eagallab for £3,000, but they did conclude the bargain for fear of attracting attention. Amdrons also bought jewels for his wife. The box which contained the stolen money remained buried for several weeks in an unknown place and it was then brought to Said Hannalla’s house and burnt there. The houses of the accused have been searched by the police. £2,723 was found in tin box built in the wall in Amdrous’s house and£400 and a quantity of jewels and valuable papers were found in Said Hannals's house. The accused deny the charge of theft, but they are being retained in prison during the enquiry.

div.head: THE STRANDED RICE BOAT.
div.p: Suez, Friday I wired yon this morning that the German (not British) steamer “Helen Rickmers" was aground near Ras Garib lighthouse in the Suez Gulf. This steamer has a full cargo of rice from Bangkok, and grounded apparently last Thursday night She was reported here yesterday by the Dutch mail boat, whioh brought her chief officer to Suez. According to the latter’s statement, the vessel is not in a bad position, and it is expected that she will come off after discharging 400/500 tons of cargo, and for this purpose several lighters and labourers are about to sail from Suez this afternoon. The Khedivial mail liner “Rahmanieh'' is also leaving Suez to-night to assist the steamer.

div.head: THE ECLIPSE IN EGYPT. SCIENTIFIC EXPEDITION.
div.p: An important American expedition is to be despatched to Upper Egypt to observe the eclipse of the sun, which will occur on August 30. The expedition will be organised and despatched under the auspices of the Lick Observatory. Mr. W.W. Campbell, director of the Lick Observatory, recently sent a communication to Secretary Shaw asking that permission bo given to the collector of the port of Now York to examine a number of scientific apparatus to be used in observing the eclipse. Included in the apparatus to be brought out are lenses, prisms, mirrors, telescopes, clocks, photograph apparatus and materials, tents, mechanics’ tools and other minor necessaries. Some of this apparatus is to bo taken from the United States Naval Observatory at Washington, from Harvard University, and from Princeton. The director stated that be would ship some of this late in May. The expeditions will start July 6 from New York. He asked also that on the return of the expeditions the instruments might be shipped in bond direct various destinations, because an examination in Now York involved danger to them on account of the unpacking and repacking. The Secretary of the American Treasury has instructed the collector to make the requested examination so that the instruments may be taken back without payment of duty. Inasmuch as the expeditions are for advancing knowledge the department makes this special ruling.

div.head: EGYPTIAN IMPROVEMENTS CORPORATION.
div.p: The above company has purchased the pro perty of Prince Mohamed Aly, brother of the Khodive, situated opposite the Savoy Hotel at Cairo, from the local syndicate that bought it lately from the Prince for L.E. 52,000. The palace and the adjoining buildings are be pulled down, the contract for their demolition having been given to Mr. Pietro Fonti, the Cairo contractor, who pays £1,500, and in return gets all tho stone and other material, the work having to be completed in five mouths. The palace, with its annexes, cost £32,000 to build eight years ago, and it stands on 1,000 square metres of ground, the total area of the property being about 7,300 square metres. On the vacant plot six large residential houses in flats will be erected.

div.head: NEW BUILDINGS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The erection of the now palatial pile, the largest of its kind in Cairo, situated opposite the Savoy Hotel, is making rapid progress, and the building will bo completed and ready for occupation by the end of the year. Including the ground floor there will be no loss than five stories, besides the basement, and the whole cost will be about £40,000, not including the site of 1,810 square metres. The masonry work was given to Messrs. Guetin and Charvand, the architect being Fabricius Pasha, who designed the handsome National Bank buildings, whilst Mr. A. St John Dia-mant is the surveyor on behalf of the Standard Life Assurance Company, for whom the new premises are being constructed. The ground floor will be partly occupied by tho oompany and partly let out as offices, and on the remaining four floors there will be eighteen residential flats on the latest and most approved principles, especially as regards the sanitary arrangements, which have been devised by Dr. II. Nolan of Cairo, and are the most perfect and scientific in the Capital. The rents of these apartments will range from £90 to £850 per annum. Throe of the larger rooms of every flat will have English fireplaces, whilst all the locks and grates as well as the lifts are being brought out from England. We understand that most of the apartments have already been let.

div.head: SHOUBRA PRIVATE HOSPITAL.
div.p: The now private Sanatorium opened at Shoubra last November by Dr. S. Voronoff, consulting physician to H.H. the Khedive, has proved a great success, judging by the large number of patients that have been admitted. Id fact for several weeks during the winter many pressing cases had to be refused admittance for want of accommodation. Miss Glewitt, the matron, formerly lady doctor at the Suez Quarantine Office, and Miss Mac-phereon, her assistant, have been kept busy since the opening. The latter has now left for England owing to ill-health, but her place will be filled later by another English nurse. The buildiug grounds surrounding were leased for four years, with option of purchase, from Mohamed Boy Abdel Wahid, a wealthy landlord of the Capital, and the gardenis 4,000 square metres in extent The mansion contains over 20 rooms, but it is intended during the summer to make several improvements and alterations which will increase the accommodation for patients. Since the opening ho less than 106 cases have been treated in the hospital, all ot which, with the exception of twelve, were surgical. Besides paying patients there are also free beds for persons of respectability who are unable from want of means to pay the fees. Dr. S. Voronoff has left for Europe on a short and much-needed holiday and until his return his duties will bo performed by Dr. G. Voronoff.

div.head: CAIRO AUTO EXCURSIONS. AN AMERICAN INNOVATION.
div.p: Plans and contracts have been completed for four electric automobiles, each to carry forty passengers at a trip, and an American youth as conductor, who will explain through a megaphone bis unlimited stock of information about the sights between Cairo and the Sphinx. The cars cost £1,000 each and will start running on the first of January next, from Shepheard’s, stopping at the Continental, Angleterre, National, and Savoy Hotels to pick up passengers. The head porters in all those hotels are financially interested in the scheme. Two trips per day, 9 a.m. and 3 p.m., are scheduled. About an hour will be spent on the road and two hours at the Pyramids. About March, the machines will bo shipped to Paris, where they will be used during the summer in seeing the sights, both day and night, much as they are now used in New York. Mr. Frank Whitcomb, the originator of these public sight-seeing autos, has carried through the deal, and will also send over to Cairo two big naphtha launches to be used as “Seeing the Nile" at ten piastres a head.

div.head: FRATRICIDE IN MENOUFIEH
div.p: A shocking crime is reported from the village of Miniat El Kobra, in the Menoofieh maiksz, Menoofieh province. A fellah, who had a grudge against his brother, attacked him from behind while he was engaged in threshing his wheat crop, and foiled the unfortunate man with several heavy blows of a about. Unfastening his turban, the murderer coolly strangled his victim, and having satisfied himself of his death, dragged the body to a neighbouring canal and threw it into the water. The body was found floating in a partly decomposed state, but the marks of the injuries sustained by the murdered man persisted and the inquiry which was held established the brother’s guilt. The murderer, who was arrested, has confessed to having committed the crime.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Port Said, Thursday. The official return for the pilgrim season of the numbers of the different classes which passed through the Canal homeward bound, show that 37 ships of different nationalities carried 33,036 pilgrims,which number includes 3,268 and Russians, 400 “varions,” the balance, 29,368, being natives of these coasts. The total loss at Tor through death is 161. 181 still remain there under treatment.
RETURN OF BRITISH BATTLESHIPS.

Apropos of the recall of the entire fleet of British battleships on the China Station, I learn that the “Canopns” and "Goliath,” whioh vessels only recently passed through the Canal, are included in the list. The others which have already received orders to return are the “Albion,’’ "Centurion," “Glory,” "Ocean," and “Vengeance.” They are to arrive here on the 14th July.
THE RECENT RIOT.

The water police officer who was badly hurt in the recent riot is now convalescent and is again on partial duty. An enquiry is in progress at the Gouvemorat into the case. Mr. Philippidis, secret service, Major Bonelli, and Schalck Bey, of the Police, have been busily engaged. The injured Arabs and police are all doing well. No farther trouble has ensued and the lesson has undoubtedly had its effect, for more Arabs are to be seen dredging for coal.
HARBOUR IMPROVEMENTS.

The back of the “Chantier des Blocs" is now being cut away and will serve as a dredger dock for the Canal Company. The heel of the new East breakwater is also under process of continuation, it being intended to form a protected bay for the floating dock there.
HASHISH SEIZURE.

A seizure of 12 demijohns of what were described on the ship's manifest and Customs declaration as mineral water took place at the custom house to-day, through the intrepidity and zeal of the teftiche officer, Ali Effendi 8abib, who called the attention of the local director (Mr. A. G. Tarroll) to the matter. Although not this officer’s special work he had his doubts, and on one being unpacked in presence of the director at the bottom hashish was found in cakes. Duty had already been paid on the “mineral water," but the director felt it his duty to retain the consignment for instruction from the Direction-General.
PERSONAL
Mr. Felix Powell, inspector in the Sanitary Administration, is due at Port Said from Cairo to-morrow night. He will stay at the Eastern Exchange.
CANAL TRAFFIC INTERRUPTED.

Port Said, Friday. At 10 a-m. to-day all canal traffic was stopped north and south of Kil. 18. It appears that one of the “Couloir” dredgers, which has been working in that locality for some weeks, had an accident to her machinery, which has resulted in the breaking of the bucket wheel and chain. These have fallen into the canal quite close to the axial line and in consequence ships are tied up north and south ot the point By sundown six will be tied up to the south and five or six from the north. Several vessels are at 8uez. Shear legs and divers have been despatched to the scene under command of the port captain.
Port Said, Saturday. The Canal was clear again for traffio at 9 o'clock last night The work of pumping and refloating the S S."Congai" will be taken in hand at daylight on Monday.
